models.FileSystemNode: A node in the prompt library file tree, representing directories or prompt fragment files.
models.Directory: A folder of prompt fragments. When renderAs='section', contains nested fields. When renderAs='field', child files are selectable options.
models.PromptFragment: A markdown file representing a selectable option within its parent directory field.
models.DirectoryConfig: Metadata configuration in a directory's config.json file controlling how it renders in Agent Builder forms.

relationships: FileSystemNode is a union type of Directory and PromptFragment
Directory contains children which are FileSystemNodes
Directory has a DirectoryConfig for metadata and field rendering behavior
PromptFragment content is inserted into template when that option is selected
Top-level directories in Prompt Library become Domains in Agent Builder

config.label: Classroom Management
config.description: Classroom characteristics, student demographics, and learning environment configuration

config.label: Grade Level
config.description: The grade level of the class

children.name: kindergarten.md
children.content:
# Kindergarten (K)

**Ages:** 5-6 years

## Key Characteristics
- Learning through play and hands-on exploration
- Short attention span (5-10 minutes)
- Developing social skills: sharing, taking turns
- Fine motor skills developing

## Teaching Tips
- Short, engaging activities with movement
- Visual supports and hands-on materials
- Consistent routines essential

children.name: 1st-grade.md
children.content:
# 1st Grade

**Ages:** 6-7 years

## Key Characteristics
- Transition to formal academics
- Beginning reading and writing development
- Attention span: 10-15 minutes

## Teaching Tips
- Balance direct instruction with hands-on activities
- Frequent checks for understanding
- Gradual increase in independent work

children.name: 2nd-grade.md
children.content:
# 2nd Grade

**Ages:** 7-8 years

## Key Characteristics
- Strengthening reading fluency
- Beginning paragraph writing
- Attention span: 15-20 minutes

## Teaching Tips
- Guided reading and writing workshops
- Math manipulatives for concepts
- Collaborative learning structures

children.name: 3rd-grade.md
children.content:
# 3rd Grade

**Ages:** 8-9 years

## Key Characteristics
- "Learning to read" shifts to "reading to learn"
- Multiplication and division introduced
- Attention span: 20-25 minutes

## Teaching Tips
- Content-area reading integration
- Project-based learning opportunities
- Introduction to test-taking strategies

children.name: 4th-grade.md
children.content:
# 4th Grade

**Ages:** 9-10 years

## Key Characteristics
- Multi-paragraph writing
- Complex problem-solving
- Attention span: 25-30 minutes

## Teaching Tips
- Research projects with multiple sources
- Collaborative work with defined roles
- Cross-curricular connections

children.name: 5th-grade.md
children.content:
# 5th Grade

**Ages:** 10-11 years

## Key Characteristics
- Final year of elementary school
- Synthesis and critical thinking
- Attention span: 30+ minutes

## Teaching Tips
- Extended research and presentation projects
- Literature circles and book clubs
- Pre-algebraic concepts introduction

children.name: 6th-grade.md
children.content:
# 6th Grade

**Ages:** 11-12 | **Middle School Year 1**

## Key Characteristics
- Transition to middle school
- Multiple teachers and subjects
- Major social transitions

## Teaching Tips
- Support transition to new routines
- Organizational systems emphasis
- Social-emotional support

children.name: 7th-grade.md
children.content:
# 7th Grade

**Ages:** 12-13 | **Middle School Year 2**

## Key Characteristics
- Peak of early adolescence
- Heightened social awareness
- Abstract reasoning developing

## Teaching Tips
- Argumentative and analytical writing
- Scientific inquiry emphasis
- Technology integration

children.name: 8th-grade.md
children.content:
# 8th Grade

**Ages:** 13-14 | **Middle School Year 3**

## Key Characteristics
- Preparing for high school
- Algebra, literary analysis
- Leadership opportunities

## Teaching Tips
- High school preparation
- Capstone projects
- Self-advocacy skills

children.name: 9th-grade.md
children.content:
# 9th Grade

**Ages:** 14-15 | **High School Freshman**

## Key Characteristics
- High school transition
- Credit-bearing courses begin
- GPA becomes significant

## Teaching Tips
- Orientation and success skills
- Note-taking strategies
- College and career exploration begins

children.name: 10th-grade.md
children.content:
# 10th Grade

**Ages:** 15-16 | **High School Sophomore**

## Key Characteristics
- AP/Honors options available
- Standardized test prep begins
- Identity exploration

## Teaching Tips
- PSAT preparation
- Research papers
- Career interest inventories

children.name: 11th-grade.md
children.content:
# 11th Grade

**Ages:** 16-17 | **High School Junior**

## Key Characteristics
- Most challenging academic year
- SAT/ACT preparation
- College considerations intensify

## Teaching Tips
- College search and planning
- Rigorous coursework support
- Junior year research projects

children.name: 12th-grade.md
children.content:
# 12th Grade

**Ages:** 17-18 | **High School Senior**

## Key Characteristics
- Culminating high school experience
- College applications
- Transition planning

## Teaching Tips
- College essay support
- Senior capstone projects
- Transition planning (college/career)

config.label: Class Size
config.description: Number of students in the class

children.name: small.md
children.content:
# Small Class Size (1-15)

## Benefits
- Individualized attention daily
- Flexible pacing based on needs
- Strong relationships
- Efficient formative assessment

## Best Strategies
- Socratic seminars
- Individual conferencing
- Personalized projects

children.name: medium.md
children.content:
# Medium Class Size (16-25)

## Characteristics
- Standard school model
- Balanced individual/group instruction
- Manageable for teacher to know each student

## Best Strategies
- Small group rotations
- Partner and collaborative structures
- Flexible grouping

children.name: large.md
children.content:
# Large Class Size (26-35)

## Challenges
- Limited individual attention time
- Assessment monitoring difficult

## Best Strategies
- Structured routines and procedures
- Cooperative learning with roles
- Peer tutoring
- Technology-assisted practice

children.name: very-large.md
children.content:
# Very Large Class Size (36+)

## Significant Challenges
- Management is primary concern
- Individual instruction highly constrained

## Essential Strategies
- Highly structured routines (every minute planned)
- Station teaching rotations
- Peer assessment structures
- Para-educator support if available

config.label: Student Support Needs
config.description: Special populations and support requirements in the class
config.hint: Select all that apply to your student population

children.name: english-language-learners.md

frontmatter.title: English Language Learners
frontmatter.description: Students who are developing English proficiency

children.content:
# English Language Learners

## Proficiency Levels
Entering → Beginning → Developing → Expanding → Bridging

## Key Strategies
- **Visual Supports:** Images, gestures, graphic organizers, realia
- **Scaffolding:** Sentence frames, word banks, modeled language
- **Comprehensible Input:** Clear speech, written notes, avoid idioms
- **Wait Time:** Extra processing time for language formulation

## Assessment
- Separate content knowledge from English proficiency
- Allow multiple demonstration formats
- Extended time for assessments

children.name: special-education.md

frontmatter.title: Special Education
frontmatter.description: Students with IEPs or specialized learning plans

children.content:
# Special Education Students

## Legal Requirements
- IEP accommodations and modifications must be implemented
- Least Restrictive Environment (LRE)
- Individualized instruction per student needs

## Key Strategies
- **Universal Design for Learning:** Multiple means of representation, engagement, expression
- **Accommodations:** Changes in *how* students learn (not what)
- **Modifications:** Changes in *what* students learn (when specified)
- **Multi-sensory Instruction:** Visual, auditory, kinesthetic approaches

## Collaboration
- Consult with special education staff
- Review IEP goals and accommodations regularly

children.name: gifted-talented.md
children.content:
# Gifted & Talented Students

## Characteristics
- Rapid learning with fewer repetitions
- Grasp abstract concepts readily
- Deep focus in areas of interest

## Key Strategies
- **Depth not Volume:** Complexity, novelty, not more work
- **Tiered Assignments:** Different complexity levels for same concept
- **Independent Study:** Pursuit of individual interests
- **Acceleration:** Subject or grade-level when appropriate

## Avoid
- Using gifted students as unpaid tutors
- Simply assigning more work
- Assuming they don't need support

children.name: reading-intervention.md
children.content:
# Reading Intervention Students

## Profile
- Reading significantly below grade level
- May have phonics, fluency, or comprehension gaps

## Key Strategies
- **Structured Literacy:** Explicit, systematic phonics
- **Fluency Practice:** Repeated reading, modeled reading
- **Audio Support:** Text-to-speech for content access
- **Decodable Texts:** Materials matching phonics knowledge

## Accommodations
- Extended time for reading tasks
- Content read aloud for subject-area access
- Audiobooks for grade-level content

children.name: math-intervention.md
children.content:
# Math Intervention Students

## Profile
- Math skills below grade level
- Missing foundational concepts
- May have developed math anxiety

## Key Strategies
- **CRA Approach:** Concrete → Representational → Abstract
- **Explicit Instruction:** Clear modeling of thinking
- **Visual Representations:** Number lines, arrays, models
- **Fact Fluency:** Strategic practice of basics

## Accommodations
- Multiplication charts and reference sheets
- Calculator for concept understanding (not computation)
- Graphic organizers for problem-solving

children.name: behavioral-support.md

frontmatter.title: Behavioral Support
frontmatter.description: Students with behavioral or social-emotional needs

children.content:
# Behavioral Support Students

## Profile
- May have BIPs, 504 plans, or other support plans
- Behavior often reflects missing skills, not willful noncompliance
- Trauma-informed approach essential

## Key Strategies
- **Clear Expectations:** Explicitly teach desired behaviors
- **Predictable Routines:** Structure provides security
- **Positive Reinforcement:** Acknowledge desired behaviors
- **Breaks:** Scheduled movement or calm-down time
- **Choice:** Limited options for sense of control

## De-escalation
- Remain calm, use neutral tone
- Give space, avoid power struggles
- Private conversations rather than public corrections

children.name: in-person.md
children.content:
# In-Person Learning

## Characteristics
- Face-to-face in physical classroom
- Immediate feedback and interaction
- Use of physical space and movement

## Best For
- Direct instruction with immediate checks
- Hands-on activities and manipulatives
- Rich social interactions
- Relationship building

children.name: hybrid.md

frontmatter.title: Hybrid
frontmatter.description: Combination of in-person and remote learning

children.content:
# Hybrid Learning

## Characteristics
- Some students in-person, some remote (or alternating days)
- Synchronous + asynchronous elements
- Technology connects all learners

## Best For
- Concurrent teaching strategies
- Station rotation models
- Digital collaboration tools
- Flexible learning environments

## Challenge
- Teacher attention divided between settings

children.name: remote.md
children.content:
# Remote/Online Learning

## Characteristics
- All instruction occurs online
- Flexible location for students and teacher
- Technology-dependent

## Best For
- Asynchronous content delivery
- Synchronous sessions for community
- Digital collaboration platforms
- Office hours for individual support

## Challenges
- Technology access and support
- Screen time management
- Building community virtually

children.name: flipped-classroom.md

frontmatter.title: Flipped Classroom
frontmatter.description: Content delivery at home, practice in class

children.content:
# Flipped Classroom

## Structure
- **Home:** Video lessons, readings, online explorations
- **Class:** Problem-solving, discussions, projects
- **Teacher Role:** Circulating, conferencing, clarifying

## Advantages
- Students can pause and rewind content
- Self-paced content delivery
- Teacher available when help is needed most

## Considerations
- Technology and internet access needed at home
- Accountability for at-home learning

config.label: Available Resources
config.description: Physical and digital resources available in the classroom
config.hint: Select all resources that are available

children.name: 1to1-devices.md

frontmatter.title: 1:1 Devices
frontmatter.description: Each student has their own device

children.content:
# 1:1 Device Program

## Uses
- Adaptive learning software (IXL, Khan Academy)
- Research and information literacy
- Digital creation (slides, videos, documents)
- Formative assessment tools (Kahoot, Quizizz)
- Collaborative platforms (shared docs)

## Considerations
- Digital citizenship education
- Screen time balance
- Device management and charging

children.name: interactive-whiteboard.md
children.content:
# Interactive Whiteboard

## Uses
- Modeling think-alouds and problem-solving
- Virtual manipulatives and tools
- Student demonstrations and sharing
- Interactive games and activities
- Annotation of texts and diagrams

## Keep Active
- Avoid passive viewing
- Have students interact with the board
- Always backup plan for technical issues

children.name: science-lab.md
children.content:
# Science Lab Access

## Uses
- Hands-on experiments and investigations
- Inquiry-based science learning
- Data collection and analysis
- Lab skills development

## Considerations
- Safety procedures and training essential
- Advance preparation and setup required
- Supervision ratios for safe lab work

children.name: library-access.md

frontmatter.title: Library Access
frontmatter.description: School library available for research and reading

children.content:
# Library Access

## Uses
- Research projects and inquiry learning
- Book selection and independent reading
- Digital literacy and database skills
- Literature circles and book clubs

## Benefits
- Diverse fiction and nonfiction titles
- Librarian support for research
- Quiet reading and study space

children.name: art-supplies.md
children.content:
# Art Supplies

## Materials
- Drawing: Paper, pencils, markers, crayons
- Painting: Watercolors, tempera, brushes
- Construction: Glue, scissors, construction paper
- Modeling: Clay, playdough

## Uses
- Creative expression and artistic skill development
- Illustrating understanding of content
- Cross-curricular projects
- Fine motor skill development

children.name: music-room.md

frontmatter.title: Music Room
frontmatter.description: Access to music facilities and instruments

children.content:
# Music Room Access

## Resources
- Instruments: Percussion, keyboards, recorders
- Large open space for movement
- Audio equipment and recording capability
- Music teacher collaboration

## Uses
- Music instruction and skill development
- Cultural exploration through music
- Performance preparation
- Integration with other subjects

children.name: gym-outdoor-space.md
children.content:
# Gym/Outdoor Space Access

## Spaces
- Gymnasium: Large indoor space
- Playground/Field: Outdoor active play
- Track/Trail: Walking or running paths

## Uses
- Physical education and motor skills
- Brain breaks and movement
- Outdoor learning and exploration
- Science observations (nature, weather)
- Team building and cooperative games

config.label: Teacher Profile
config.description: Teacher experience, specialization, and teaching preferences

children.name: 0-2-years.md

frontmatter.title: 0-2 years (Novice)
frontmatter.description: Early career teacher building foundational skills

children.content:
# 0-2 Years Experience (Novice)

## Profile
- Building foundations, steep learning curve
- Energy and enthusiasm for new ideas
- Benefits from mentorship and structured guidance

## Strengths
- Open to new approaches
- Current on educational theory
- Technologically adept

## Growth Areas
- Classroom management consistency
- Pacing and planning efficiency
- Parent communication confidence

## Advice
- Focus on a few key practices
- Seek mentorship actively

children.name: 3-5-years.md
children.content:
# 3-5 Years Experience

## Profile
- Finding groove, developing confidence
- Establishing consistent routines and approaches
- Beginning to differentiate and vary instruction

## Strengths
- Beginning to understand student development
- Classroom management becoming more automatic
- Can plan more efficiently

## Growth Areas
- Deepening content knowledge
- Data-driven instruction
- Special populations expertise

children.name: 6-10-years.md
children.content:
# 6-10 Years Experience

## Profile
- Solid foundation of management and instruction
- Planning efficiently, managing multiple demands
- Can analyze and adjust based on results

## Strengths
- Strong classroom management
- Deep understanding of curriculum
- Effective parent communication

## Growth Areas
- Avoiding stagnation
- Mentoring newer teachers
- Leadership opportunities

children.name: 11-20-years.md
children.content:
# 11-20 Years Experience

## Profile
- Extensive experience across contexts
- Highly effective with most students
- Often in leadership or mentoring roles

## Strengths
- Deep understanding of development
- Viable strategies for most challenges
- Efficient systems and routines

## Growth Areas
- Avoiding cynicism or burnout
- Staying current with trends
- Work-life balance

children.name: 20-plus-years.md
children.content:
# 20+ Years Experience

## Profile
- Career-long dedication to teaching
- Seen trends come and go
- Valued for historical perspective and expertise

## Strengths
- Incredible depth of experience
- Master classroom manager
- Wealth of strategies

## Considerations
- Risk of becoming set in ways
- Stay curious and open to innovation
- Mentor while being open to learning from newcomers

config.label: Subject Expertise
config.hint: Select all areas of certification or expertise

children.name: mathematics.md
children.content:
# Mathematics Expertise

## Content Areas
- **Number Sense:** Place value, operations, fractions, decimals
- **Algebra:** Patterns, equations, functions, proportional reasoning
- **Geometry:** Shapes, transformations, measurement, spatial reasoning
- **Statistics:** Data analysis, graphing, probability

## Pedagogy
- Concrete-Representational-Abstract progression
- Multiple representations (visual, symbolic, verbal, contextual)
- Focus on conceptual understanding before procedures

children.name: english-language-arts.md
children.content:
# ELA Expertise

## Content Areas
- **Reading:** Foundational skills, fluency, comprehension strategies
- **Writing:** Process writing, genres, grammar, conventions
- **Speaking & Listening:** Discussion skills, presentations
- **Language:** Vocabulary, conventions, etymology

## Pedagogy
- Balanced literacy approach
- Reader's and writer's workshop models
- Integration of reading and writing

children.name: science.md
children.content:
# Science Expertise

## Content Areas
- **Physical Science:** Matter, energy, forces, motion
- **Life Science:** Organisms, ecosystems, heredity, evolution
- **Earth & Space:** Geology, weather, astronomy, water cycle
- **Engineering Design:** Problem-solving, iteration

## Pedagogy
- Scientific inquiry and investigation
- Hands-on experimentation
- Science and engineering practices

children.name: social-studies.md
children.content:
# Social Studies Expertise

## Content Areas
- **History:** Events, figures, periods, cause and effect
- **Geography:** Maps, places, regions, human-environment interaction
- **Civics:** Citizenship, democracy, laws, institutions
- **Economics:** Resources, production, consumption, trade

## Pedagogy
- Inquiry-based learning
- Primary source analysis
- Multiple perspectives and historiography

children.name: art.md
children.content:
# Art Expertise

## Content Areas
- **Elements:** Line, shape, color, texture, form, space, value
- **Principles:** Balance, contrast, emphasis, movement, pattern, unity
- **Media:** Drawing, painting, sculpture, printmaking, digital
- **Art History:** Styles, periods, artists, cultural contexts

## Pedagogy
- Creative expression and experimentation
- Art appreciation and visual literacy
- Studio processes management

children.name: music.md
children.content:
# Music Expertise

## Content Areas
- **Elements:** Rhythm, melody, harmony, form, timbre, expression
- **Theory:** Notation, scales, intervals, chords, composition
- **History:** Periods, composers, styles, cultural traditions
- **Performance:** Vocal and instrumental techniques

## Pedagogy
- Active music-making (singing, playing, creating)
- Music literacy development
- Cultural and historical contexts

children.name: physical-education.md
children.content:
# Physical Education Expertise

## Content Areas
- **Motor Skills:** Locomotor, non-locomotor, manipulative
- **Fitness:** Cardiovascular, strength, endurance, flexibility
- **Games & Sports:** Skills, strategies, rules, sportsmanship
- **Anatomy:** Body systems, exercise science

## Pedagogy
- Age-appropriate skill progression
- Modification for all ability levels
- Lifetime fitness focus

children.name: special-education.md
children.content:
# Special Education Expertise

## Knowledge Areas
- **Disabilities:** Specific learning disabilities, autism, emotional/behavioral
- **Legal:** IDEA, FAPE, LRE, due process
- **IEP Process:** Referral, evaluation, planning, implementation
- **Instruction:** Specially designed instruction

## Pedagogy
- Accommodations vs. modifications
- Universal Design for Learning
- Positive behavior support
- Collaboration with general education

children.name: esl-ell.md
children.content:
# ESL/ELL Expertise

## Knowledge Areas
- **Acquisition:** Theories, stages, factors affecting language learning
- **Proficiency:** WIDA levels, entering through bridging
- **Linguistics:** Phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics
- **Programs:** Bilingual, sheltered, dual language models

## Pedagogy
- Sheltered instruction (SIOP, GLAD)
- Content and language objectives
- Building on home language assets

children.name: direct-instruction.md
children.content:
# Direct Instruction

Teacher-led, explicit teaching with clear modeling.

## Best For
- Introducing new skills or content
- Teaching procedures and routines
- Ensuring all students access core content
- Clarifying misconceptions

## Key Elements
- Clear learning objectives
- Modeling and think-alouds
- Guided practice with feedback
- Independent practice

children.name: inquiry-based.md
children.content:
# Inquiry-Based Learning

Student-led investigation and discovery.

## Best For
- Science and social studies investigations
- Developing critical thinking
- Building curiosity and engagement
- Memorable learning experiences

## Key Elements
- Compelling questions
- Investigation and research
- Evidence-based conclusions
- Communication of findings

children.name: cooperative-learning.md
children.content:
# Cooperative Learning

Structured group work with individual accountability.

## Best For
- Practice and review activities
- Complex problem-solving
- Social skill development
- Diverse perspectives

## Key Elements
- Clear group goals and individual roles
- Face-to-face interaction
- Interpersonal skills taught explicitly
- Group processing/reflection

children.name: project-based-learning.md
children.content:
# Project-Based Learning

Extended projects with authentic real-world connections.

## Best For
- Integrating multiple subjects
- Deeper understanding and application
- Student engagement and relevance

## Key Elements
- Driving question or challenge
- Sustained inquiry
- Authentic context and audience
- Student decisions and reflection
- Public product

children.name: differentiated-instruction.md
children.content:
# Differentiated Instruction

Responsive teaching adjusted to student needs.

## What's Differentiated
- **Content:** What students learn
- **Process:** How students learn
- **Product:** How students demonstrate learning
- **Environment:** Conditions for learning

## Best For
- Diverse classrooms with varied readiness
- Multiple learning profiles
- Ensuring access and engagement for all

children.name: gamification.md
children.content:
# Gamification

Game design elements to increase motivation.

## Best For
- Skill practice and repetition
- Building engagement
- Progress tracking
- Positive class culture

## Key Elements
- Clear goals and rules
- Progress tracking and feedback
- Rewards and recognition
- Narrative or context
- Balanced challenge

children.name: general-elementary.md
children.content:
# General Elementary Certification

- **Grades:** Typically K-6 or K-8
- **All Subjects:** Qualified to teach all core subjects
- **Focus:** Child development and learning, cross-curricular integration

- Generalist rather than specialist
- Strong understanding of learning progressions

children.name: subject-specific-secondary.md
children.content:
# Subject-Specific Secondary Certification

- **Grades:** Typically 7-12 or 5-12
- **Subject Area:** Certified in specific content area(s)
- **Focus:** Adolescent development, secondary methods

Common areas: Math, English, Sciences, Social Studies, Foreign Languages, Art, Music, PE

children.name: special-education.md
children.content:
# Special Education Certification

- **All Grades:** K-12 or grade-band specific
- **Focus:** Specialized instruction, IEP development and implementation
- **Expertise:** Behavior management, collaboration, case management

Critical shortage area in many districts

children.name: esl-ell-endorsement.md
children.content:
# ESL/ELL Endorsement

- **All Grades:** Typically K-12
- **Focus:** Second language acquisition, sheltered instruction
- **Expertise:** Working with culturally and linguistically diverse students

May pull out students or co-teach with general education

children.name: gifted-education.md
children.content:
# Gifted Education Certification

- **All Grades:** Typically K-12
- **Focus:** Advanced learners, acceleration and enrichment strategies
- **Expertise:** Social-emotional needs of gifted students, identification

Often combined with other responsibilities

children.name: reading-specialist.md
children.content:
# Reading Specialist Certification

- **Focus:** Advanced expertise in literacy instruction
- **Role:** Reading intervention, literacy coaching, RtI coordination
- **Expertise:** Reading acquisition, assessment, interventions, dyslexia

Works with struggling readers and supports other teachers

config.label: Professional Development Goals
config.placeholder: Describe areas for growth or improvement...

config.label: Curriculum Standards
config.description: Curriculum frameworks, standards alignment, and learning objectives

children.name: common-core.md
children.content:
# Common Core State Standards (CCSS)

## English Language Arts
- **Key Shifts:** Content-rich nonfiction, evidence-based reading/writing, complex text
- **Strands:** Reading, Writing, Speaking/Listening, Language
- **Literacy:** History/Science technical subjects included

## Mathematics
- **Key Shifts:** Focus, coherence, rigor (conceptual understanding, procedural skill, application)
- **Domains:** Operations, algebra, geometry, measurement, data, fractions, ratios, functions, statistics

Focus on college and career readiness

children.name: ngss.md
children.content:
# Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS)

## Three Dimensions
1. **Disciplinary Core Ideas:** Physical, Life, Earth/Space Science, Engineering
2. **Science & Engineering Practices:** Questioning, modeling, investigating, analyzing, arguing
3. **Crosscutting Concepts:** Patterns, cause/effect, systems, energy/matter, structure/function

Performance expectations integrate all three dimensions

children.name: teks.md
children.content:
# Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKS)

- **State Standards:** Texas-specific K-12 curriculum
- **All Subjects:** Comprehensive across all content areas
- **STAAR Alignment:** State assessment aligned to TEKS

**Key Features:**
- Readiness Standards (essential for success)
- Supporting Standards (introduced, not essential)
- Process Standards (ways of thinking within each discipline)

children.name: state-specific.md
children.content:
# State-Specific Standards

States that developed their own standards (not CCSS).

Examples:
- **Virginia:** Standards of Learning (SOL)
- **Minnesota:** Academic Standards
- Other individual state standards

Vary in organization and emphasis from national models

children.name: international-baccalaureate.md
children.content:
# International Baccalaureate (IB)

## Programmes
- **PYP (ages 3-12):** Transdisciplinary, learner profile focus, exhibition
- **MYP (ages 11-16):** Subject groups, global contexts, personal project
- **DP (ages 16-19):** Diploma programme, university recognition

## Key Features
- Concept-based curriculum
- International-mindedness
- Approaches to teaching and learning skills

children.name: cambridge-international.md
children.content:
# Cambridge International Curriculum

## Pathway
- **Primary:** Ages 5-11
- **Lower Secondary:** Ages 11-14
- **Upper Secondary:** IGCSE, ages 14-16
- **Advanced:** AS & A Levels, ages 16-19

## Key Features
- Internationally recognized qualifications
- Clear progression across stages
- Skills development: critical thinking, problem-solving
- University acceptance worldwide

children.name: formative.md
children.content:
# Formative Assessment

**Assessment FOR Learning** - ongoing checks to guide instruction

## Strategies
- Exit tickets and quick checks
- Think-pair-share and discussion
- Whiteboard responses
- Observation during work
- Questioning and conferences

## Purpose
- Identify who understands and who needs help
- Guide instructional next steps
- Provide feedback to students

children.name: summative.md
children.content:
# Summative Assessment

**Assessment OF Learning** - evaluates learning at the end of instruction

## Types
- End-of-unit tests and projects
- Final exams
- Standardized assessments
- Performance tasks
- Portfolios (cumulative)

## Purpose
- Determine mastery of standards
- Assign grades for reporting
- Evaluate program effectiveness

children.name: portfolio-based.md

frontmatter.title: Portfolio-Based
frontmatter.description: Collection of student work over time

children.content:
# Portfolio-Based Assessment

Collection of work gathered over time showing growth and achievement.

## Types
- **Growth Portfolio:** Shows progress and development
- **Showcase Portfolio:** Best work demonstration
- **Process Portfolio:** Documents learning process

## Advantages
- Shows growth over time
- Captures complexity of learning
- Student ownership and agency

children.name: project-based.md
children.content:
# Project-Based Assessment

Students complete meaningful, real-world projects.

## Characteristics
- Authentic, real-world context
- Requires higher-order thinking
- Extended time to complete
- Public product or presentation

## Assesses
- Process as well as product
- Collaboration and communication
- Content knowledge application

children.name: standardized-testing.md
children.content:
# Standardized Testing

Uniform assessment administered to all students under same conditions.

## Types
- State accountability assessments
- District benchmarks
- Nationally normed tests (Iowa, Stanford)
- College entrance exams (SAT, ACT)
- English proficiency assessments (ACCESS)

## Purpose
- Comparability across students/schools
- Accountability and program evaluation

children.name: performance-tasks.md
children.content:
# Performance Tasks

Students apply knowledge and skills in authentic tasks.

## Characteristics
- Real-world context
- Multiple steps and solution paths
- Extended time to complete
- Clear evaluation criteria

## Examples
- Science lab investigations
- Mathematical problem-solving tasks
- Writing prompts with research
- Speaking and listening demonstrations

children.name: mathematics.md
children.content:
# Mathematics

## Core Domains
- **Number & Operations:** Counting, place value, operations, fractions, decimals
- **Algebra:** Patterns, equations, functions, proportional reasoning
- **Geometry & Measurement:** Shapes, attributes, transformations, measurement
- **Statistics & Probability:** Data, graphs, likelihood

## Mathematical Practices
1. Make sense of problems and persevere
2. Reason abstractly and quantitatively
3. Construct arguments and critique reasoning
4. Model with mathematics
5. Use appropriate tools strategically
6. Attend to precision
7. Look for and use structure
8. Express regularity in repeated reasoning

children.name: english-language-arts.md
children.content:
# English Language Arts

## Core Components
- **Reading:** Foundational skills, literature, informational, fluency, comprehension
- **Writing:** Types (narrative, informational, opinion), process, conventions
- **Speaking & Listening:** Comprehension, collaboration, presentation
- **Language:** Conventions, vocabulary acquisition

## Text Complexity
- Quantitative measures (lexile, readability)
- Qualitative measures (structure, language, knowledge demands)
- Reader and task considerations

children.name: science.md
children.content:
# Science

## Core Domains
- **Physical Science:** Matter, forces, motion, energy, waves
- **Life Science:** Molecules to organisms, ecosystems, heredity, evolution
- **Earth & Space:** Earth's place, systems, human impact
- **Engineering:** Design process, technology connections

## Science & Engineering Practices
- Asking questions, defining problems
- Developing and using models
- Planning and carrying out investigations
- Analyzing and interpreting data
- Using mathematics and computational thinking
- Constructing explanations, designing solutions
- Engaging in argument from evidence
- Obtaining, evaluating, communicating information

children.name: social-studies.md
children.content:
# Social Studies

## Core Disciplines
- **History:** Historical thinking, context, evidence, arguments
- **Geography:** Spatial thinking, places, regions, physical/human systems
- **Civics & Government:** Civic life, government structure, constitutional principles, citizenship
- **Economics:** Scarcity, economic systems, markets, national economy, global economy

## Skills
- Critical thinking and analysis
- Primary and secondary source analysis
- Geographic literacy
- Civic participation

children.name: art.md
children.content:
# Visual Arts

## Elements of Art
Line, Shape, Form, Color, Texture, Value, Space

## Principles of Design
Balance, Emphasis, Movement, Pattern, Rhythm, Unity, Proportion

## Media & Techniques
- Drawing: Pencil, charcoal, pastel, ink
- Painting: Watercolor, tempera, acrylic
- Sculpture: Clay, found materials
- Printmaking: Relief, stamping
- Collage and mixed media

## Art Appreciation
Periods, styles, artists, cultural contexts, critique

children.name: music.md
children.content:
# Music

## Musical Elements
- **Rhythm:** Beat, meter, tempo, patterns
- **Melody:** Pitch, contour, scales, intervals
- **Harmony:** Chords, accompaniment, texture
- **Form:** AB, ABA, rondo, theme/variation
- **Expression:** Dynamics, timbre, style

## Musical Skills
- Vocal: Posture, breath, pitch matching, part-singing
- Instrumental: Technique, notation, ensembles
- Literacy: Notation, composition, improvisation

## Musical Contexts
Music history, periods, composers, world music, American music

children.name: physical-education.md
children.content:
# Physical Education

## Motor Skills
- **Locomotor:** Walk, run, hop, gallop, skip, leap, jump
- **Non-Locomotor:** Bend, stretch, twist, balance
- **Manipulative:** Throw/catch, kick/punt, strike, dribble, volley

## Physical Fitness
- **Health-Related:** Cardiovascular, strength, endurance, flexibility, body composition
- **Skill-Related:** Agility, balance, coordination, power, reaction time, speed

## Social Responsibility
Goal setting, cooperation, teamwork, fair play, safety, etiquette

children.name: health.md
children.content:
# Health Education

## Personal Health & Wellness
- **Physical:** Nutrition, activity, sleep, hygiene
- **Mental/Emotional:** Emotions, stress management, self-esteem, mental health awareness
- **Social:** Relationships, conflict resolution, peer pressure, bullying prevention

## Safety & Prevention
- Personal safety, emergency procedures, internet safety
- Substance abuse prevention, peer influence

## Growth & Development
- Body knowledge, puberty, reproduction, family diversity

## Community Health
Community resources, environmental health

children.name: computer-science.md
children.content:
# Computer Science

## Computational Thinking
- Decomposition: Breaking problems into parts
- Pattern Recognition: Finding similarities
- Abstraction: Focusing on important information
- Algorithm Design: Step-by-step procedures

## Programming
- **Concepts:** Sequences, loops, events, conditionals, variables, functions
- **Block-Based:** Scratch, Blockly
- **Text-Based:** Python, JavaScript

## Digital Literacy & Citizenship
- Digital devices, internet and networks
- Online safety, evaluating information, ethical use, copyright

## Data and Applications
Robotics, game design, web development

children.name: introduction.md
children.content:
# Introduction Level

First exposure to content. Concrete, tangible examples.

## Targets
- Recognize and identify basic concepts
- Understand key vocabulary
- Follow simple procedures with support
- Make connections to prior knowledge

## Support Needs
- Clear step-by-step instructions
- Scaffolding and guided practice
- Multiple examples and models

children.name: developing.md
children.content:
# Developing Level

Building understanding, moving toward independence.

## Targets
- Apply skills with increasing independence
- Explain reasoning and processes
- Recognize patterns and relationships
- Solve familiar problems

## Support Needs
- Strategic prompting and cues
- Partially completed examples
- Graphic organizers and visual supports

children.name: proficient.md
children.content:
# Proficient Level

Solid understanding, independent application.

## Targets
- Apply skills to novel situations
- Explain thinking with clear reasoning
- Make connections across concepts
- Choose appropriate strategies
- Solve multi-step problems

## Support Needs
- Extended challenges and enrichment
- Choice in approach and representation

children.name: advanced.md
children.content:
# Advanced Level

Deep understanding, abstract reasoning, synthesis.

## Targets
- Analyze complex problems and situations
- Evaluate arguments and evidence
- Create original solutions or products
- Transfer learning to unfamiliar contexts
- Synthesize information from multiple sources

## Support Needs
- Minimal scaffolding, consultation when needed
- Authentic, real-world challenges

children.name: extension.md
children.content:
# Extension Level

Beyond grade-level, expert-like understanding.

## Targets
- Novel applications and creations
- Transfer across domains
- Critique and refinement of work
- Development of expertise

## Support Needs
- Expert guidance and feedback
- Access to professional resources
- Time for deep exploration

children.name: literacy.md
children.content:
# Literacy Integration

## Reading Across Content Areas
- Content area reading strategies
- Disciplinary literacy (how experts read)
- Academic vocabulary development
- Text complexity access

## Writing Across the Curriculum
- Writing to learn: Journals, quick writes
- Argument writing: Claim-evidence-reasoning
- Informative/explanatory writing
- Writing frames and scaffolds

children.name: numeracy.md
children.content:
# Numeracy Integration

## Math in Science
- Data analysis: Collecting, representing, interpreting
- Measurement: Precision, units, error
- Proportional reasoning: Scaling, rates

## Math in Social Studies
- Data interpretation: Charts, graphs, statistics
- Timeline and chronology
- Geography: Coordinates, scale, distance
- Economics: Budgets, percentages

## Real-World Numeracy
- Financial literacy
- Measurement in daily life
- Statistics in media

children.name: technology.md
children.content:
# Technology Integration

## Productivity Tools
- Word processing, spreadsheets, presentations
- Cloud storage and collaboration

## Subject-Specific Tools
- Science: Simulations, data sensors, digital microscopes
- Math: Graphing tools, geometry software
- Humanities: Digital archives, research databases

## Digital Citizenship
- Online safety and privacy
- Evaluating online information
- Responsible communication
- Copyright and ethical use

children.name: arts-integration.md
children.content:
# Arts Integration

## Visual Arts
- Drawing to show understanding
- Diagrams and models for concepts
- Infographics combining text and visuals
- Color and emotion in literature/history

## Performing Arts
- Historical reenactment
- Acting out scientific processes
- Bringing texts to life
- Role-playing social situations

## Music
- Educational songs for memory
- Rhythm and mathematical patterns
- Cultural music for understanding

children.name: real-world-applications.md
children.content:
# Real-World Applications

## Community Connections
- Local issues: Environmental, social, civic problems
- Local history and primary sources
- Service learning projects
- Community experts and professionals

## Career Connections
- How subjects connect to professions
- Real-world professional problems
- Professional tools and methods

## Current Events
- News analysis using content concepts
- Real data from news and research
- Civic engagement opportunities

## Personal Relevance
- Financial literacy
- Health and wellness decisions
- Environmental stewardship

children.name: social-emotional-learning.md
children.content:
# Social-Emotional Learning (CASEL Framework)

## Self-Awareness
Emotions, strengths/challenges, confidence, growth mindset

## Self-Management
Impulse control, stress management, self-discipline, motivation

## Social Awareness
Empathy, perspective-taking, appreciating diversity, respect

## Relationship Skills
Communication, teamwork, conflict resolution, seeking/helping

## Responsible Decision-Making
Ethical considerations, consequences, problem-solving, safety

## Integration Strategies
- Explicit teaching of SEL skills
- Morning meetings and class circles
- Literature with SEL themes
- Restorative practices

# 5th Grade

**Ages:** 10-11 years

## Key Characteristics
- Final year of elementary school
- Synthesis and critical thinking
- Attention span: 30+ minutes

## Teaching Tips
- Extended research and presentation projects
- Literature circles and book clubs
- Pre-algebraic concepts introduction
